awd_titl_txt: Organic Superconductors and Conductors in High Magnetic Fields
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In the framework of our project DMR-1104512, we (Prof. Andrei Lebed and graduate student Otar Sepper) have theoretically studied unique electronic properties of superconducting and unusual metallic (the so-called non-Fermi-liquid) phases in high magnetic fields. In the case of superconducting phase, for the first time, we have demonstrated that superconductivity can be stable at ultrahigh magnetic fields (up to 1000 Tesla and higher), in contrast to common believe that magnetic fields always destroy superconducting phase. This phenomenon, discovered by us in the grant, may become an important step in the creating of superconducting wires and devices, which are stable in ultrahigh magnetic fields at ultrahigh electric currents. Another discovered by us phenomenon is that magnetic fields can change the physical nature of electron in some solids, which are called quasi-one-dimensional conductors. We have shown that, at high magnetic fields, in such solids electrons cannot be considered anymore as a sea of colliding hard balls (which is called Fermi-liquid), but completely lose their individualities and sometimes may be even converted into other type of particles - the so-called bosons. The above-mentioned latter sub-topic of our researches (i.e., non-Fermi-liquidity) may become important for a search of novel types of electric conductivity in strong magnetic fields. University of Arizona science writer Emily Litvack has published news release, describing our discovery of non-Fermi-liquidity at high magnetic fields (see, for example, https://www.technology.org/2015/10/07/losing-individuality-electrons-identity-crisis/). Our project has had an impact on human resource development in science and technology. It has provided an opportunity for research and education in such vital areas of solid state physics as superconductivity and correlated electrons as well as computing languages and applied mathematics for a graduate student Otar Sepper. Andrei Lebed’s course of lectures Phys-263H "intro to Quantum Mechanics and Relativity" for undergraduate students of Physics Department at the University of Arizona contains some recent examples from the project activity, which enriches other students knowledge in the areas of superconductivity, Bose-Einstein condensation, and highly correlated electrons.
